Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mainland Southeast Asia in the Longue Duree: a test of the "Broad Spectrum Revolution" in Northern Thailand

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of New Mexico Ph.D. student Cyler Conrad, under the supervision of Dr. Emily Lena Jones, will investigate how Thai hunter-gatherers responded to environmental shifts and the introduction of domesticated plants and animals over the past 12,000 years. Previous archaeological research indicates that hunter-gatherers often broaden their diets to include previously ignored animal resources due to changes in environmental conditions, increases in human population densities or both. In some cases, these activities lead to increased human-animal interaction and eventually domestication, while in others they facilitate the continued long-term exploitation of wild animals by hunter-gatherer groups. Given the documented changes to human societies that follow domestication, research on the archaeological record of hunter-gatherers who lived through the transition to agriculture provides a means to examine how and why these shifts occurred, as well as providing information on how hunter-gatherer populations impacted the adoption of domesticated animals and plants in a region where they continue to forage alongside agriculturalists today. In a globalized world with complex indigenous rights issues as well as a loss of traditional knowledge and subsistence practices, this project will examine how long-term archaeological record of hunting and animal exploitation articulates with modern hunter-gatherer lifeways and wild animal conservation issues.

In this project, Conrad will test the "Broad Spectrum Revolution" hypothesis at a suite of sites from northern Thailand, a region in which this hypothesis has never been formally tested. Northern Thailand was 1) the first region in Thailand where these domesticates were introduced and 2) a region where the extant wild progenitors of these domesticated animals originally lived and were (and continue to be) exploited by hunter-gatherers. Using both analysis of animal bone from these sites and biochemical testing of animal teeth and mollusk shell, Conrad will explore how hunter-gatherers altered (or not) their exploitation of wild animals in response to changes in environmental conditions and to the introduction of domesticated plants and animals. This multi-faceted approach will provide fine-grained data on wild animal hunting before, during, and after the period when domestic plants and animals were first introduced. The data produced by this project will be an important proxy for understanding how future environmental changes in the Southeast Asian tropics may impact traditional subsistence strategies and domesticated animal husbandry. In addition, this project will support professional collaborations between American and Thai scholars and will result in the creation of a bilingual museum exhibit presenting project results at the Natural History Museum of the National Science Museum, Thailand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how northern Thailand hunter-gatherers responded to environmental shifts and the introduction of domesticated plants and animals over the past 12,000 years using a combination of zooarchaeological, radiocarbon and luminescence dating, and stable isotope analyses from four archaeological sites. These sites include Spirit Cave, Steep Cliff Cave, Banyan Valley Cave and Non Nok Tha. During the 1970s, archaeologists working in northern Thailand informally argued that a Broad Spectrum Revolution (BSR) occurred sometime around the Pleistocene-Holocene transition, approximately 10,000 years ago. The BSR hypothesis states that hunter-gatherer populations (non-farmers) broaden their diet to include previously ignored animal resources due to changes in environmental conditions, increases in human population densities or both. Although previous archaeologists applied this hypothesis to the northern Thailand prehistoric record, and argued for its validity, this NSF funded dissertation research project identifies that a true BSR likely did not occur within this region. Analyses of radiocarbon dates suggest fluctuations in hunter-gatherer demography, but not any major shifts that should occur with a BSR. Similarly, analyses of stable isotopes suggest possible phases of paleoenvironmental change, specifically reforestation during the mid-Holocene, but not a dramatic period of environmental change as predicted by the BSR hypothesis. Finally, results from the investigation of animal bones and shell from archaeological sites in northern Thailand indicates that hunter-gatherers practiced long-term, consistent, and sustainable, exploitation of a select few animal resources. These results run counter to expectations based on the BSR hypothesis and suggest that within northern Thailand, there is a distinct prehistoric human population, subsistence and environmental record.

Through this NSF funded project, the co-PI received his dissertation, which was successfully defended on May 11, 2018. The completed traditional dissertation includes six chapters: an introduction, background to the BSR and the study sites in northern Thailand, hunter-gather demography and radiocarbon dating, paleoenvironmental change and stable isotopes, subsistence and zooarchaeology, and a conclusion chapter summarizing the results of the BSR hypothesis test. All dissertation materials, including appendices, data, and R programming code created during this project are publicly available through the University of New Mexico Digital Repository (after a two-year embargo period ending in 2020). Thus far, a single peer-reviewed manuscript has been published sharing background information relating to this research project. During this dissertation project, all faunal remains from Spirit Cave, Steep Cliff Cave, Banyan Valley Cave and Non Nok Tha were re-bagged and catalogued using museum quality archival materials, and these collections are now easily accessible at the Penn Museum and the Ban Chiang National Museum for use by future researchers. Through this project, important collaborations were facilitated between the co-PI and the Fine Arts Department, Thailand, and the Natural History Museum, National Science Museum, Thailand. Methods and results of sampling modern mammals from the Natural History Museum for stable isotopes helped establish a baseline dataset for future Thai researchers to access and study. Collaboration with curators at the Natural History Museum also helped establish the framework for a future museum exhibit dedicated to the zooarchaeology and faunal diversity of northern Thailand, including a public display focused on stable isotopes in archaeology.
